DOCNAME: CASE OF EL BOUJAÏDI v. FRANCE
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr ORG was born in GPE in DATE and is a NORP national . In DATE he went with his mother , his CARDINAL sisters and his brother to join his father in GPE . He has been living in GPE since enforcement on CARDINAL DATE of an order for his permanent exclusion from NORP territory .
CARDINAL . The applicant went to school in GPE , where he also worked for DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE a network of traffickers in heroin imported from the GPE was discovered in the LOC ( LOC ) . CARDINAL people , including the applicant , were committed for trial at FAC charged with consumption of and trafficking in prohibited drugs .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Saint - Etienne Criminal Court sentenced Mr ORG to CARDINAL GPE imprisonment , to run concurrently with another sentence of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment imposed by ORG on DATE for dealing in heroin , and ordered him to pay customs fines . Applying LAW , it further imposed permanent exclusion orders on Mr ORG and CARDINAL of his co - defendants and a DATE exclusion order on a fourth .

CARDINAL . On appeal by the prosecution , ORG , in a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , increased the applicant ’s sentence to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment , with ineligibility for parole during the first CARDINAL thereof , and confirmed the permanent exclusion order . The reasons for the judgment were set out as follows :

“ In DATE , in the course of an inquiry aimed at breaking up a heroin - trafficking network operating in FAC , the police arrested [ the applicant ] , who had been named as a supplier by various users .

During questioning by the police and the investigating judge ORG admitted that he had been using heroin for DATE and that he injected himself with up to QUANTITY per day . According to his statements , he obtained his supplies from [ K. , A. and NORP ] , who obtained their supplies in GPE .

Again according to his own statements , ORG had been peddling heroin since DATE to finance his own consumption . He even stated at CARDINAL interview that each time he bought QUANTITY he sold on CARDINAL .

The various users named in the charge as buyers from ORG confirmed during the course of the inquiry that they had obtained varying quantities of heroin from him throughout the relevant period , namely from DATE to DATE .

According to the statements made by a number of these buyers , ORG was known to drug addicts in FAC as a supplier and users could meet him in a bar in Place PERSON , where the transactions took place .

ORG was found guilty of selling heroin to [ B. ] in a judgment of GPE [ Criminal ] Court of DATE , which has become final . There is therefore no need to rule on that offence . As regards the remaining charges , and in view of the extreme seriousness of the accused ’s conduct , the ORG upholds the guilty verdict referred from the court below and sentences ORG to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment , to run concurrently with the DATE sentence passed on DATE by ORG ...
The ORG orders [ the applicant ’s ] permanent exclusion from NORP territory .
CARDINAL . On DATE , pleading his family ties in GPE , Mr ORG lodged a first application to have the order permanently excluding him from NORP territory rescinded .

In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG declared the application inadmissible on the ground that under LAW CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW an alien permanently excluded from NORP territory could not apply for the relevant order to be rescinded .

CARDINAL . Following an attempted robbery , the applicant DATE who had been released on DATE – was arrested and , on DATE , detained under a committal warrant . For this offence and the fact that he had stayed in GPE in spite of the permanent exclusion order imposed on him , on DATE FAC sentenced him to DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr ORG again applied to have the exclusion order rescinded . He submitted that the length of time he had been living in GPE brought him into a category of convicted aliens on whom , under LAW , in its new version as amended by the Law of CARDINAL DATE , an exclusion order could not be imposed . He also argued that on account of his family ties in GPE the exclusion order was in breach of LAW .
CARDINAL . ORG refused this application on DATE in a judgment containing the following reasons :

“ The applicant has submitted not only that the order permanently excluding him from NORP territory should be rescinded in the light of LAW ... but also that , as a matter of fact , he has lived in GPE since DATE and the whole of his family lives here too .

While Mr ORG application has become admissible since the repeal by the PERSON of DATE ... of the last paragraph of LAW CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW , the applicant can not rely on the substantive provisions of that legislation , which are not retrospectively applicable to convictions that became final , as in this case , before its entry into force .
His application must accordingly be dealt with on its own merits , on the basis of LAW .
Mr ORG has adduced no new evidence since his conviction on CARDINAL DATE .
He can not argue , as an unmarried man , that his exclusion from NORP territory is an intolerable interference in his family life within the meaning of LAW ...
The offences he has committed , after CARDINAL previous convictions for drug offences , make his presence on NORP territory dangerous for public health and public order .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ) dismissed an appeal on points of law lodged by the applicant on DATE against the judgment of ORG on the ground that Mr ORG statement of the grounds of appeal did not bear his signature .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr ORG made a third application requesting ORG to rescind the exclusion order . In support of his appeal – which was based on LAW he pleaded changes in his personal circumstances , namely the fact that he was living with a NORP , PERSON , and was the father of the child she had given birth to on DATE .
On DATE the social worker at the prison where Mr ORG was detained wrote to his lawyer in the following terms :

In reply to your letter of CARDINAL DATE concerning the steps taken over DATE regarding recognition of the child of Mr ORG , currently imprisoned , for whose social welfare I am responsible , I can inform you that , at the request of Mr ORG and [ PERSON , his cohabitant :

CARDINAL . In DATE I prepared the paperwork for a prenatal recognition of paternity and sent the file both to the town hall of PERSON and to ORG so that the appropriate submissions could be made to ORG .

CARDINAL . As this application had been unsuccessful and the child had been born – on DATE – I compiled a new recognition of paternity file and sent it on DATE to ORG at the Saint - Etienne tribunal de grande instance .
CARDINAL . On DATE the exclusion order was enforced .
CARDINAL . On DATE , at FAC in Fez , Mr El Boujaïdi recognised paternity of PERSON child .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ORG refused the application to have the exclusion order rescinded on the following grounds :

“ Mr ORG lawyer has produced various documents showing that Mr ORG met PERSON in DATE , that is at a date when he should not have been present on NORP territory . Their child was born on DATE . The circumstances he relies on therefore came into being at a time when he was permanently excluded from NORP territory .
The exclusion order was imposed to penalise a dangerous trade in heroin . That being so , the ORG does not see fit to allow the present application .
CARDINAL . Relying mainly on LAW and ORG case - law , the applicant appealed on points of law . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the appeal on the following grounds :

“ The judgment under appeal shows that ORG , who is a NORP national , was sentenced , inter alia , to be permanently excluded from NORP territory for an offence against the dangerous drugs legislation , in a judgment of ORG of CARDINAL DATE , which has become final , and that by an application dated DATE he sought to have that exclusion order rescinded .

In rejecting that application ORG observed that the family circumstances on which the appellant relies came into being while he was permanently excluded from NORP territory . It further stated that the purpose of the additional penalty imposed on the appellant was to ‘ penalise a dangerous trade in heroin’ .

… Article CARDINAL of LAW does not prohibit limitations prescribed by law on the right to respect for family life , provided that they are necessary for , among other things , public safety , the prevention of disorder and the protection of health . That is the position in the present case .
It follows that the appeal , which amounts to a challenge to the ORG discretionary power under LAW , then in force , can not be allowed .
CARDINAL . Article L. CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW formerly provided :
“ ... the courts ... may order an alien convicted of an offence under LAW to be permanently excluded from NORP territory .
Exclusion from NORP territory shall of itself entail the deportation of the convicted person at the end of his sentence .
Where a person , on conviction , is permanently excluded from NORP territory , he may not request the benefit of the provisions of LAW . ”
Law no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE replaced the last CARDINAL paragraphs by the following provisions :
“ However , exclusion from NORP territory shall not be imposed on :

CARDINAL . a convicted alien who is the father or mother of a NORP child resident in GPE , provided that he or she is vested with or shares parental authority over that child or provides for its needs ;
Nor shall exclusion from NORP territory be imposed on a convicted alien who can prove either :
CARDINAL . that he has been normally resident in GPE since reaching DATE at the most or for DATE ; or
CARDINAL . that he has been lawfully resident in GPE for DATE .
Exclusion from NORP territory shall of itself entail the convicted person ’s deportation , where necessary after the end of his prison sentence . ”
LAW was repealed by Law no . CARDINAL of DATE .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provides :

Any person who has incurred a disability ... as an automatic consequence of a criminal conviction or on whom such disability ... has been imposed by the convicting court in its judgment ... may request the court which convicted him ... to rescind the disability ... , in whole or in part , or vary its duration .
